data.title: Sweet Land (2005)
data.meta_description: Set in 1920, Inge travels from Germany to rural Minnesota in order to meet the man destined to be her husband.
data.text:
“Sweet Land” feels like someone with little experience in filmmaking was handed a pocketful of change to make a movie about their grandparents. It sounds like a backhanded compliment, but it’s meant favorably. I’m sure many of us would jump at the chance. My own grandparents, all of which were born in the midst of World War II in Nazi Germany, have told me numerous stories of their childhood that would certainly be worthy of a big screen treatment as well. Such an intimate connection is not actually the backstory here, as Ali Selim adapted the material from a short story, but it felt deeply personal nonetheless. Without much fanfare yet lots of heart, “Sweet Land” tells a fairly simple…

Wait... this is the music from Nebraska.

As a decedent of Lutheran Norwegian and German immigrants and a Minnesota native, this film has sparked a curiosity in me to learn about my family's history and culture. But even without that person connection, there is a lot to appreciate about Sweet Land. The romance it explores my not be breaking new ground, but it gives an authentic look into Norwegian-American culture in the Midwest, and the unfortunate exclusivity that many communities have had throughout most of American history. However, through small instances of love and connection, our social bonds began to spread to more and more diverse webs.

Even if a German-Norwegian couple doesn't seem all that revolutionary now, it's the…
